An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.
Does the concept of a/an Factorial ring/unique factorization domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Prime Element to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Prime Element explicitly states that it is an element in a unique factorization domain (UFD), also known as a factorial ring. This means that the concept of a prime element is inherently tied to the structure of a UFD. In a UFD, every non-zero, non-unit element can be uniquely factored into prime elements, and the definition of a prime element involves its behavior in relation to other elements within this domain, specifically its ability to divide products of elements. Without the structure and properties of a UFD, the definition of a prime element as given would not make sense because the properties that characterize a prime element (such as dividing a product implies dividing at least one factor) rely on the unique factorization property of the domain. Therefore, the concept of a factorial ring or UFD is necessary for the definition of a prime element to be meaningful and applicable.
